you use white background.

```
I see #1808135 but as I understand it was about 6.0.0, and fixed March 14.

In 5.1.2 (released later) I noticed the bug which is related to that but I
can't say mirroring doesn't work.

In footprint editor open QFN-28-1EP_4x4mm_P0.45mm_EP2.4x2.4mm_ThermalVias.
Increase the scale to see '1' in pad 1.

title: Common python+Cpp API access pcb and eschamtic file? (lp:#1831166)
description:
[Original report](https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1831166) created by **NhatKhai (nhatkhai)**
```
I think it would be great if we have a well define API from Cpp, and can be
access from python to read, write import objects in pcbnew, and eschematic.

This allow:
* Others can develop separate code to convert/translate to difference file
format for ECAD simulation
* Whatever file format Kicad change in future do not effect and external
code
* Event main KiCad itself should use this API. So any new file format do
not impact the code already work.
* New file formats may be access naively when some one can implement to
support current API interface.
* Someone can create a converter from netlist to schematic. Or a simulator
result mode to schematic model.

Importance object mostly to allow to do simulation on schematic level or
pcb level.
```
Original tags: eeschema feature.request python

title: Button/hotkey to recompute net on tracks and vias (lp:#1831046)
description:
[Original report](https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1831046) created by **Simon Richter (sjr)**
```
As an easier workflow to reassign a trace from one net to another, it would
be nice if there was a button to recompute the net of tracks and vias from
the connected pads.

This would allow the user to disable DRC, connect the track to a different
pad, recompute nets and reenable DRC, while currently they would have to
disconnect the track, change the net assignment for the next and all
connected segments (which is difficult because many of the nets have long
names computed from the numbers of connected pads), and then connect the
track to the other pad.
```

title: Enable individual symbols and footprints in library tables (lp:#1830946)
description:
[Original report](https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1830946) created by **Seppe Stas (seppestas)**
```
This is a feature request / request for comments

I think it would be nice to have some sort of "filter" option for entries
in a library table, especially for symbol libraries. Some use-cases:

- When using some else's libraries you can only have symbols and footprints
that you have already double checked show up by default (my primary use-
case)
- Find symbols that are already used in a project easier / faster
- Reduce the time needed to load libraries

To elaborate on my use-case:

In the company I work for we maintain our own KiCad library with symbols
and footprints. These symbols and footprints where often made by ourselves,
but sometimes symbols and footprints where copied from third party
libraries like the KiCad official libraries. This kind of sucked, since it
was often not clear where the symbols came from, what changes where made to
it and if changes where made they could not easily be contributed back.

We are now trying a new system where we add third-party libraries as git
submodules in our library, however we stumbled upon one limitation we
didn't have when working just copying symbols: we can no longer just select
specific symbols from the third party library. This is important, since we
often found mistakes / quality issues in third party libraries (and even
though the quality of the official libraries improved a lot, we still can't
trust it blindly).

For footprint libraries it is possible to symlink specific specific
footprints into an "in-between" library but this is a bit tedious to
maintain.

For symbol libraries, we came up with a "SYMBOLS" field in the library
table options field. This SYMBOLS filed contains a space separated list of
symbols in the library that have been "double checked" and used in some
project. This way when we start a new project, we can use the symbols in
the "SYMBOLS" list as if we made them ourselves and we now we have to be a
bit more careful with third-party symbols not in this list.

Having a little checkbox to "enable" a symbol in the symbol library browser
that automatically maintains this list would make this approach a lot more
convenient. The same approach could be applied to footprint libraries. When
placing a symbol / selecting a footprint an option could shown to only show
/ load filtered symbols / footprints.

If it's OK I plan to implement this soon and send a patch to the developer
mailing list. I looked into developing it as a plugin, but it's not really
possible to hook in on the symbol selection dialog as far as I can see.

To reduce impact on the library table format I think the "Options" field
could be used, but having a dedicated field might be nicer. Having a
newline separated list would make it nicer to keep track of changes in git
however, i.e a simple git blame could show when a symbol was added to the
list.
```

title: Adding a new library to the global library table will happily use KIPRJMOD by default (lp:#1830694)
description:
[Original report](https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1830694) created by **Rene Poeschl (poeschlr)**
```
Adding a library to the library table automatically replaces the file
system path with path variables if possible. This is generally a good
thing. But the use of KIPRJMOD in a global library table will most likely
be a mistake by the user. Meaning simply using it without asking any
questions might not be the best idea.

Example: The user makes a new library using the library editor. It by
default points the user to the location of the project. New users might
simply create the library that way and select "global" in the next dialog
(as they do not know what global/local means). KiCad will then use KIPRJMOD
in the path without the user ever being aware that they might want to
change this. (Which will lead to an error message when opening a different
project.)

There are two options from this point. Adding a project local library to a
global library table could print a warning message that this is not
considered a good idea or kicad could use the full path instead of path
variables. (I lean towards the former as the most likely case here is a
misunderstanding of kicads library system.)
```

title: eeschema hierarchical sheet copy-paste looses child sheet content (lp:#1830633)
description:
[Original report](https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1830633) created by **Dino Ghilardi (dino-ghilardi)**
```
Using copy-paste on a child sheet block to have two sheets coming from the
same file creates an empty sheet, possibly loosing data.

To reproduce the bug:

1 Create a project
2 Create a new hierarchical sheet (using "Add a hierarchical sheet").
2.5 Put something inside it (components, connections, etc.)
3 Go back to the parent sheet.
4 use copy-paste to create a new hierarchical sheet. It has the same file
reference (correct)
5 if you enter the new created sheet it is empty (not correct, it should be
the same as the copied sheet).
  if you save the schematic now you loose the old child sheet content. It
seems it is overwritten by the new empty one having the same filename.

6: Workaround: If you edit the properties of the new block in the parent
sheet (shortcut E or right-click->properties), do not change anything and
confirm: a dialog asks for confirm, then the child sheet loads the correct
schematic in it.

Quicker (more dangerous) way to reproduce the bug:
-Open a schematic (that has a backup somewhere) with some hierarchical sub-
sheet
-copy-paste one of them
-save-->...data lost.

title: pcbnew net names on tracks only shows when zoomed in (lp:#1830344)
description:
[Original report](https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1830344) created by **bwack (hanspd)**
```
I'm using a 1600x1200 desktop.
After going from 4.0.7 -> 5.1.0, I've noticed that in pcbnew i need to
zoomed in on tracks much more than before for net names on tracks to be
visible. I find myself zooming in and out more often.

screenshot:

Legacy toolset, net names visible on thin tracks:
https://imgshare.io/image/2019-05-24-10-38-37-pcbnew-d-documents-
github-c64-saver-bwac.rg09Y

Modern toolset (fallback), net names not visible:
https://imgshare.io/image/modern-toolset.rgHon

Modern toolset (fallback) zoomed in as far as needed to see netnames:
https://imgshare.io/image/kicad-5-1-0-zoomed.rgLdP

Other observations:

- selecting a track in zoomed out will show net name on that track.
Allthough small, they are very visible with high rendering option.
https://imgshare.io/image/modern-toolset-selected.rgk89

- highlighting a net will not show net name on tracks (zoomed out (Home))

My question then is, if the netnames on thin tracks are easily readable,
why hide them? When I make a screenshot of the layout for review on github,
I find it best take screenshot. Plot does not give the same quality as the
actual screen rendering. To get all the net names on tracks I zoom in and
take 4x4 tile screenshots (easier than it sounds, but still..), then
concatinate them with imagemagick, and resize to ordinary size, and still
the net names are readable on the thinnest traces that I showed in the
first screenshot. example:
https://raw.githubusercontent.com/bwack/C64-Saver-
bwack/develop/addon%20board/C64Saver2-addon.kicad_pcb_1_3.png

title: Footprint Editor crashes when unfolding a library and scrolling (lp:#1830331)
description:
[Original report](https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1830331) created by **Bart Bilos (sq-uantmuts)**
```
Hello all,

When editing a project and then going into the footprint editor I noticed a
few of my libraries having no subcomponents while they are there, when
unfolding the library above it and scrolling, I see strange footprints
named "0",<li><u>JEDEC</u> and such and then kicad crashes with a
segmentation fault. If anybody can point me how to get additional debug
information output that I see in some other crash reports, I would provide
it. I have installed kicad-dbg but when running kicad it is still the

title: bus members with the same name are merged (lp:#1830233)
description:
[Original report](https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1830233) created by **Dino Ghilardi (dino-ghilardi)**
```
If two different buses have members with the same name they are connected
together even if in the schematic there is no connection.

To reproduce the behaviour:
-create two buses using tools->bus definitions, with buses having some
members with the same name
-draw the two buses on the schematic, adding a label over the buses with
the name of the bus
-unfold the members that have the same name
-use "highlight wires and pins of a net" to see that they are connected.
-Also in the netlist passed to pcbnew they will be connected.

...as a workaround we could use different names for every bus member, but
this solution is not optimal (and has drawbacks too).

One possible solution should be using a bus member naming convention for
the bus member like
BUS_NAME[n] (with n numeric) for the buses like address bus A[0] A[1] etc..
BUS_NAME[member_name] for the named members,
but (of course) may be a better approach.
```

description:

```
Placing a hierarchical sheet label on a bus end does not turn the label
blue and clicking the label does not show bus informations.

Workaround: drag the bus or the label with the "g" shortcut and when placed
(and deselected) turns blue correctly. Selecting it afther this operation
shows the correct bus information in the bottom status bar.

To reproduce:
1) create a bus definition using tools->bus definitions
2) draw a bus line on the schematic
3) add a label on the bus with the same bus name defined before
4) add a hierarchical sheet label at the end of the bus.

Placing the label it will not turn to the "bus color".

Drag it and it will.
Move it and place it back where it was and it will.

```
The Sexpr test leak memory:

==13786== 56 bytes in 1 blocks are definitely lost in loss record 129 of
244
==13786==    at 0x4838DEF: operator new(unsigned long)
(vg_replace_malloc.c:334)
==13786==    by 0x12BD6E:
SEXPR::PARSER::parseString(std::__cxx11::basic_string<char,
std::char_traits<char>, std::allocator<char> > const&,
__gnu_cxx::__normal_iterator<char const*, std::__cxx11::basic_string<char,
std::char_traits<char>, std::allocator<char> > >&) (sexpr_parser.cpp:93)
==13786==    by 0x12B98D:
SEXPR::PARSER::Parse(std::__cxx11::basic_string<char,
std::char_traits<char>, std::allocator<char> > const&)
(sexpr_parser.cpp:46)
==13786==    by 0x125922:
TEST_SEXPR_PARSER_FIXTURE::Parse(std::__cxx11::basic_string<char,
std::char_traits<char>, std::allocator<char> > const&)
(test_sexpr_parser.cpp:44)
==13786==    by 0x121E86: SexprParser::ParseExceptions::test_method()
(test_sexpr_parser.cpp:141)
==13786==    by 0x12176D: SexprParser::ParseExceptions_invoker()

title: Replace wxTimer in SCH_EDITOR_CONTROL by timestamp (lp:#1830202)
description:
[Original report](https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1830202) created by **Simon Richter (sjr)**
```
In SCH_EDITOR_CONTROL, there is a timer that is started after a search, and
if another search is started while the timer is still running, the search
may wrap to the start.

No action is taken or needed when the timer elapses, so this could be done
a bit more lightweight by saving the event timestamp from the last search
and comparing the timestamp from the current search.

In addition, it would be nice if that mechanism wouldn't use a global
object.

Offending line:

eeschema/tools/sch_editor_control.cpp:213:    static wxTimer
wrapAroundTimer;
```

title: Zone stitching vias don't have nets updated in v6 (lp:#1830102)
description:
[Original report](https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1830102) created by **Seth Hillbrand (sethh)**
```
Importing an Eagle project from [1], version 5.1.x does well.  There are no
unconnected nets and the netnames are properly assigned to all items on
import.

In version 6, there are 4 vias that stitch together two zones (no tracks
connected).  These keep an original net name from Eagle instead of being
updated.  The vias are then unconnected as are the two zones.

Schematic" changes more items on the board.

as v6

title: eeschema - unfold from bus: double labels in popup menu (lp:#1829878)
description:
[Original report](https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1829878) created by **Dino Ghilardi (dino-ghilardi)**
```
Using the "unfold from bus" right-clicking on a bus lists twice the bus
member names.
Doing it with the shortcut "C" works correctly.

To reproduce the behaviour:
-Define a bus with bus->tools definitions and define
-Draw a bus on the schematic
-Put the name on the bus with "add a net label"
-right-click on the bus and choose "Unfold from bus"
--> probably now you will see "bus has no connections", but this is another
bug: to workaround it, if the label is still black, drag the bus under the
label, than it becomes blue and the bus name is set.


In the menu where to choose the net every bus member is reported twice

Also when the menu reports twice "bus has no connections" the second is
selectable and unfolds a net with name "bus has no connections".

```
I'm used to work with PCB with white background, and wonted to use KiCad in
'my' colours. When I've changed background colour to white the coursor is
still visible, but when I try to place a line (in footprint editor) or
place a track in PCB editor coursor disapears. I believe there is no place
where I can set coursor colour.
The same problem is with Measure distance tool.

I think if coursor colour can't be set by user then not automatically
adapting its colour to background (at least to two oposities - back and
white) is a bug. This is not connected with any user interface change so I
think can be done in V5.

    KICAD_SCRIPTING_MODULES=ON

    BUILD_GITHUB_PLUGIN=ON

Reproduction of bug:

Python 2.7.15 (default, Oct 11 2018, 12:09:51)  [GCC 8.2.0 64 bit (AMD64)]
on win32
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> from pcbnew import *
>>> brd = LoadBoard('test_dr.kicad_pcb')
>>> drs = brd.GetDesignSettings()
>>> drs.m_HoleToHoleMin
37845792  <== I don't know where this value comes from.
>>> drs.SetMinHoleSeparation(12345678)
>>> drs.m_HoleToHoleMin
12345678  <== New hole-to-hole setting.
>>> brd.SetDesignSettings(drs)
>>> brd.Save('test_dr.kicad_pcb')  <== Save updated board.
True
>>> brd = LoadBoard('test_dr.kicad_pcb')  <== Reload updated board.
>>> drs = brd.GetDesignSettings()
>>> drs.m_HoleToHoleMin
0         <== Updated hole-to-hole setting has been lost.
>>>

This same problem affects m_RequireCourtyards and
m_ProhibitOverlappingCourtyards.
The only commonality I can see is that none of these member variables have
the drs.Get*()
methods (e.g. drs.GetMinHoleSeparation()).

reference) positions correctly. Saving, closing and reopening the pcb will

title: Eagle import: milling layer is converted to edge cuts layer (lp:#1829708)
description:
[Original report](https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1829708) created by **Rene Poeschl (poeschlr)**
```
The milling layer defines where the milling tool should remove material.
(The centerline defines the toolpath and the width defines the diameter of
the cutter)

The center of lines on the edgecuts layer in kicad (as far as i understand
it) defines the resulting nominal border of the board. (The cutter is
offset from it by half its diameter)

Right now kicad converts lines on the milling layer directly to edge cuts
lines. If my interpretation of the edge cuts layer is correct then the
lines should be converted to two lines and arcs at the end such that the
cutout is defined properly. Or a new layer must be introduced that does the
same as the milling layer in eagle.

Edit: If the edge cuts layer can double as the milling layer (if my
understanding of it is incorrect) then the line width of features on the
milling layer would need to be used for resulting features on the edge cuts
layer. (Right now the edge cuts lines get the default width)

---

title: Converting text to a label can create a label with illegal characters (lp:#1829664)
description:
[Original report](https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1829664) created by **Chris Elliott (sembazuru)**
```
While confirming a potential bug on the forum I discovered that I can
create a label with spaces (I don't recall off the top of my head any of
the other illegal label characters, so I didn't try them).

When normally creating a label the text input box doesn't insert anything
when the space bar is pressed. Also, if when creating a label one is able
to get a space into the text input box by pasting a string containing
spaces, an error is thrown when the OK button is clicked. Both of these
behaviors are expected.

One can create a normal text that includes spaces. (This is also expected.)
BUT, then one can convert this text into a label, and now one has a label
with spaces. ERC doesn't flag this. If one edits this label-with-spaces the
OK button will throw an error, but the cancel button doesn't. An error
should be thrown when first attempting to convert the text to a label if
the text contains illegal characters for labels.

See the attached screenshot of a label (indicated by black character color)
with spaces.

description:

```
If you open the footprint library browser (from the symbol properties
dialog for example) and open the 3D viewer, this window will be sent back
to the background if the fp lib browser window get activated.

- Open a schematics, full screen
- Open a symbol properties dialog from this schematics
- Open the Footprint Library Browser (click on the right end of the
Footprint/Value row)
- Open the 3D viewer (which now has the focus)
- Activate / select the Footprint Library Browser
